module_meta_data.name: Week 3 Project - Console Games with JS

pageBreakdown.title: Week 3 Project - Console Games with JS

Functions
Each of the games will be start when their respective functions are called.

madLibs function
Use string concentration to insert variables into a string

rockPaperScissors function
➔ Convert the user’s choice to lowercase.
➔ Validate user’s choice by checking if it’s “rock”, “paper”, or “scissors”.
➔ Use return statement to exit function and return undefined.

rockPaperScissors function (cont.)
➔ Check remaining possible combinations of choices.
◆ If user choice is rock and the computer’s is paper, than the computer wins.
◆ Else, user wins.

rockPaperScissors function (cont.)
➔ Check remaining possible combinations of choices.
◆ If user choice is paper and the computer’s is scissor, than the computer wins.
◆ Else, user wins.

rockPaperScissors function (cont.)
➔ Check remaining possible combinations of choices.
◆ If user choice is scissors and the computer’s is rock, than the computer wins.
◆ Else, user wins.

coinFlip function 
➔ Convert user’s choice to lower case.
➔ Check that it’s “heads” or tails”. If not, use return statement to exit the function and return undefined.
➔ Generate random number.
➔ Use number to choose “heads” or “tails”.
➔ Compare the user’s and computer’s choice and determine winner.
➔ Return statement

The HTML boilerplate
➔ Create a new file called index.html
➔ Title to create title
➔ Link element links to the stylesheet that we will make in a while

HTML Part 1
➔ Create a body and a calculator div

JS Setup
➔ Add a script tag under all the elements
➔ Includes all the JS for the project

JS Part 1
➔ Global variable value will store current numbers on calculators
➔ Global variable cursor will store where the cursor is
➔ Place in script tag

JS Part 4
➔ Make keys change the calculator state
➔ Create a function called keyHandler(e) that takes a single argument
➔ Use e.key to get the key name
➔ To bind the function to the document, use the following:

CSS with HTML
➔ Create a new file called style.css. (Right click on a file, and hit "New File". Then, click "Lesson Wide" - This is EXTREMELY IMPORTANT!
➔ The link element in the html code will link to the css file
➔ What css will do:
◆ Add styling for header, elements, etc.
◆ Add the calculator font

CSS Part 3: Calculator Div
➔ Use .calculator selector to select calculator class
➔ box-shadow gives a little shadow around calculator
➔ width and height use calc css method to make them 30 pixels less than the full width and height
➔ max-width and max-height make sure the calculator can only expand a certain amount
➔ position: absolute makes sure the calculator stays where it is and doesn’t move when other elements move
➔ left and top push the top right corner of the element to the middle
➔ transform centers the image after the top right corner has been moved

CSS Part 6: Media + Value
➔ @media makes css run only under certain conditions (ie. when the max-width is 400px)
Getting ready to publish to NPM

module_meta_data.name: Week 7 Project - Information Displayer with React

pageBreakdown.title: Week 7 Project - Information Displayer with React

Setting up our workspace
Important: You can skip this step if you are following along in 
➔ Let’s first setup a React.JS app in replit. (Hit create and then select “react” as a language)
➔ Then, create a component called “header”, and import it into your project (You can put anything you want in here)
➔ Next, let’s create another folder inside of “components” named “infoDisplayer,” and create a file named “infoDisplayer.jsx” inside of it
➔ Lastly, import it into “main.jsx” again.

infoDisplayer.jsx
➔ Inside of this file, first create a function with a parameter named “props”. 
➔ Then, display some props like “stats” (Like name, age, favorite color, etc.)
➔ Lastly, export this function
➔ Just a refresher, access the props with {props.yourPropName} 
➔ When you run the project right now, you probably won’t see much, but we’ll change this in the next slide

Passing in props
To actually make the website show info, we need to pass in some props into the React component
➔ To call this, just pass in the props like you would with standard HTML attributes (ex. name=”FooBar”)

module_meta_data.name: Week 8 Project - To Do List with React Components

pageBreakdown.title: Week 8 Project - To Do List with React Components

Getting everything ready
We want our React app to have two major components: The item displayer/remover and the item adder. Something like below

Item List Component
Inside the Item List component, let’s loop over a prop named “list”
Inside, just create a div with key of element.key and contents of element.itemName

Item List component (testing)
To test our component, first go to main.jsx and import the module if you haven’t already.
Then, pass the “list” prop to it which contains an array of things. (We’ll be changing this later to handle use input)

Add Item Component
➔ First, create an input element with a ref
➔ Then, create a button that runs a function 
➔ “addItem” when clicked
➔ If you don’t know any of these, it’s highly recommended to view the instruction slides, but here’s the code for your convenience

➔ For the main parent to receive updates whenever a user clicks “update,” we need to change the main page to a class. 
➔ Then, we can create a callback function and pass it down to the child
➔ In our case, the callback function is called “callBackFunction” (creative, right?). We then pass this to the AddItem component through a prop called “callback”

Accessing the callback
➔ To access the callback function made available to us in the previous slide, access the prop named “callBack” and then run it with a parameter with a value of whatever’s in the textbox
➔ Now, we can add something in the text box, and it will log it into the console!

Updating the list
➔ To make the list update every time a user inputs a new item, we need to use React States
➔ Create a React State named “items” and inside it, put our previous “items” variable
➔ Then, pass this React State to the ItemList component. Then, every time the callback function is called, add a new element to that array and update the state!

Making delete buttons
We’re almost there! We just need to make the delete buttons so users can delete items!
➔ First, add an X element and style it as you wish.
➔ Then, create a function named “deleteItem” that runs a callback with a key.
➔ Lastly, add an onClick listener that runs this function with it’s key.

Last step! Updating main.jsx
Great! We just need to do one more thing! Add the callback functions in main.jsx
➔ First, create a function called “deleteCallback” that takes the parameter “key” that when called, deletes that index from the array with the “splice” function. Lastly, update the item state
➔ Then, pass this function as a prop named “callBack” to “itemList.jsx”

webdev-projects.desc: Put your HTML, CSS, JS, React, and Express.JS skills to use! Create useful web apps, publish your first package for others to use, and much, much more!

ai.desc: Students will be skilled in topics such as tree AI, regression, SVM, neural networks, computer vision, NLP, and unsupervised learning. Python is primarily used.

intro-to-cs.desc: Students will be able to demonstrate loops, functions, classes, and more in their Python code. They will be able to solve USACO-style problems with these tools.
